results.title: National Ranger 505 Transistor TV
results.creator_credit: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.description:
National Ranger 505 Transistor TV is a portable TV with handle, small screen and folding antennae. The television was completely portable - it could be powered with either mains power or batteries, allowing the user to kick back and take the TV to the beach, campground or backyard.

National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: Hanimex Rondette 400S 35mm colour slide projector
results.brief_description: “Hanimex Rondette 400S 35mm colour slide projector Made in New Zealand f2.8 projector 8.5mm 230 - 240 V 50CYC A.C. Only 60W Use 12V 50W Iodine Quartz Lamp. Made in New Zealand by Hanimex Manufacturing Ltd. Green guarantee sticker on the bottom: N.Z. No 37229 Housed in original cardboard box. Air New Zealand MELBOURNE destination tag stapled to top of the box. Purchased from Christchurch International Duty Free Shop. 3 slides: - Man in Traditional dress. ‘Taken on Board Rasa Sayang. Handwritten label: BL 23 - Test slide for Reflector Adjustment - Kodachrome transparency of 3 men performing in a band. Standard 36 Han-O-Matic Magazine original box with index printed on outside. Kindermann (Adapter Rachmen) original red cardboard box. 37 Kindermann Adapters for 110 slides. Made in West Germany. Three plastic 110 Film slide viewers Paperwork included: Kodacolour II Film Instructions Hanimex La Rondette 400S QI Instructions Hanimex Magazine Instructions Hanimex Guarantee card”

results.title: EUMIG Mark 607D Dual 8 Silent Projector
results.brief_description:
“EUMIG Mark 607D Dual 8 Silent Projector Made in Austria 100/250V 50/60 Hz 145W Pr.Lampe Max 75W 12V serial number: 5274584 Housed in original cardboard box, foam inner in two pieces. Separate power cord with Australian plug. 1 empty reel Instruction manual Eumig guarantee certificate Peter Chews shop introduction card in a promotional bookmark format. Eumig service instructions Lamp Economy Switch print-out”

This projector is in a working condition, tested Feb 2020.
*Possibly purchased from Peter Chew’s shop, Singapore. Shop card found with warranty.

results.title: We Dream of Networks
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson
fibre-tipped pen, fibre-tipped markers and gouache on paper
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: fibre-tipped pen, fibre-tipped markers and gouache on paper
results.brief_description:
Jess Johnson was born in Aotearoa/New Zealand in 1979, and lives and works in New York. Her drawing and installation practice is influenced by science fiction, language, culture and technology. In her drawings she depicts complex worlds that combine densely layered patterns, objects and figures within architectural settings. Johnson’s drawings are often displayed within constructed environments that act as physical portals into her speculative worlds. Her video collaborations with Simon Ward have involved translating her drawings into animated Virtual Reality, thus enabling her audience to have the simulated experience of entering the hypnotic realms depicted in her drawings. Jess Johnson’s work has been exhibited Internationally in solo exhibitions at; Jack Hanley Gallery, New York; Art Basel, Hong Kong; Nanzuka Gallery, Tokyo; Talbot Rice Gallery, Edinburgh; National Gallery of Australia; Museum of Contemporary Art, Australia; Auckland Art Gallery and Christchurch Art Gallery, New Zealand.

Jess Johnson is represented by Darren Knight Gallery, Sydney; Ivan Anthony Gallery, Auckland and Jack Hanley Gallery, New York

results.title: Spellbound Concerto record
results.brief_description: Though the theremin is most commonly associated with science fiction, it was first used in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945). For a dream sequence designed by Surrealist artist Salvador Dali, composer Miklós Rózsa used the theremin’s strange reverberations to produce unease and psychological tension.
